{{Refimprove|date=May 2018}} '''Stephen David Ross''' (born 1935) is an American philosopher, currently Distinguished Research Professor of Philosophy, Interpretation, and Culture and of Comparative Literature at [[Binghamton University]]. He has published over 30 books in interdisciplinary philosophy, especially on art, literature, ethics, and metaphysics, from American pragmatism through poststructuralism, from human beings to animals and things.
==Biography== He was born May 4, 1935 to Allan Ross and Bessie Schlosberg. He studied mathematics at [[Columbia University]] where he received an MA in 1957, and a PhD in philosophy in 1961. He taught philosophy at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and the University of Colorado in Boulder before moving to [[Binghamton University]]/[[State University of New York]] in 1967. He married Marilyn Gaddis Rose in 1968.
He spent the rest of his teaching career in Binghamton where he helped create two interdisciplinary PhD programs, one in Philosophy, Literature, and the Theory of Criticism in the Department of Comparative Literature, the second in Philosophy, Interpretation, and Culture (PIC), located first in the Department of Philosophy, later becoming an independent program. He was appointed Distinguished Professor of Philosophy, Interpretation, and Culture and of Comparative Literature in 2006. He is currently Alfred North Whitehead Fellow in the [[European Graduate School]], Saas-Fee, Switzerland. He was editor of the journal [[International Studies in Philosophy]] from 1979-2011.
==Work== His career has been devoted to different possibilities of expressing and living with uncertain beliefs, unsettled experiences, and inexhaustible realities. He has explored different forms of writing and varied terminologies for expressing what resists expression, based on the conviction that such a resistance requires constant vigilance and innovative writing, the constant production and transformation of forms of knowledge, especially including philosophy, whose relations to art, literature, science, and religion enrich it profoundly with novel and imaginative questions and answers.
He began in American pragmatism, reading it to question itself fundamentally and to entail the ''inexhaustibility'' of nature and reason, the [[:wikt:mystery|mysteriousness]] of things. He wrote several books on ordinality and an ''ordinal metaphysics'', influenced by his mentor, [[Justus Buchler]]. He turned then to [[Alfred North Whitehead]] and his notion of prehension or perspective. A universe of orders composed of orders composing other orders, of perspectives, is an inexhaustible universe without totality. Everything is limited, including every limit, an inexhaustible play of limit and unlimit.
In 2002 he came to believe that such a sense of inexhaustibility required a very different style of writing, more literary and oblique, and found this in post-Heideggerian writings, especially [[Michel Foucault]], [[Jacques Derrida]], [[Emmanuel Levinas]], and [[Deleuze and Guattari]]. ''The Ring of Representation'' was written in sonorous and voiced verbs—ringing, sounding—avoiding all forms of the verb "to be" so as to question the question of Being.
An ongoing theme throughout his work was that of an infinite ethics, infinite in each decision and inclusive of all things. This led him to Levinas's notions of ''betrayal'' and ''generosity'', two notions that would deeply influence his writing. Betraying contains a double meaning, violation and revelation. He linked it with [[Anaximander]]'s notion of injustice in all things, later defining it as the nonidentity of every identity with itself, a systematic and pervasive sense of how nature and reason exceed themselves, with evolution a foremost example of the first, art and literature of the second.
This was followed by seven volumes on gifts and generosity, undercutting the sense of possessing and having that color traditional views of knowledge, truth, and being. Then followed explorations of images in philosophy and art, understanding the world as images, a different way of thinking of perspectives. Images proliferate from other images, revealing and betraying them. This double movement of betraying led to books on enchantment and [[disenchantment]], on asking and telling, to a novel, returning to an infinite and inclusive ethics through animals and other things.
These all express a sense of unceasing [[question]]ing, and questioning that questioning, that he suggests is profoundly ethical: ethical fullness.
==Some publications== * 2018: ''A Life in Question'', Amazon Publishing * 2017: ''Ethical Fullness: Thinking of Animals, Believing in Things'', Amazon Publishing * 2013: ''A Philosophy Fiction'', Atropos Press * 2013: ''Betraying Derrida, for Life, Perhaps'', Atropos Press * 2012: ''Unsettling: Asking, Telling, Doing, Betraying'', Atropos Press, European Graduate School * 2012: '' Asking, for Telling, by Doing, As if Betraying'', Atropos Press * 2012: '' [[Wonder (emotion)|Enchanting]]: Beyond [[Disenchantment]] '', SUNY Press * 2009: ''Un [[forgetting]]: Re calling [[Time]] Lost'', Globall Academic Publishing * 2008: ''The World as [[Aesthetics|Aesthetic]] Phenomenon'', Global Academic Publishing * 2005: ''The Gift of [[Self]]: Shattering, Emptiness, Betrayal'', Global Academic Publishing * 2001: ''The Gift of [[Property]]: Having the Good, Betraying Genitivity, Economy and Ecology: An Ethic of the Earth'', SUNY Press * 1999: ''The Gift of [[Created kind|Kind]]s: The Good in Abundance: An Ethic of the Earth'', SUNY Press * 1998: ''The Gift of [[Touch]]: Embodying the Good'', SUNY Press * 1997: ''The Gift of [[Truth]]: Gathering the Good'', SUNY Press * 1997: ''Ideals and Responsibilities: Ethical Judgment and Social [[Identity (social science)|Identity]]'', Wadsworth Publishing Company * 1996: ''The Gift of [[Beauty]]: The Good as [[Art]]'', SUNY Press * 1995: ''Plenishment in the [[Earth]]: An [[Ethic]] of Inclusion'', SUNY Press * 1994: ''Locality and Practical Judgment: Charity and [[Sacrifice]]'', [[Fordham University]] Press * 1994: ''The Limits of [[Language]]'', [[Fordham University]] Press * 1993: ''[[Injustice]] and [[Restitution]]: The Ordinance of [[Time]]'', SUNY Press * 1992: ''The Ring of [[Representation (arts)|Representation]]'', SUNY Press * 1989: ''[[Metaphysics|Metaphysical]] [[Aporia]] and [[Philosophy|Philosophical]] [[Heresy]]'', SUNY Press * 1989: ''Inexhaustibility and [[Human Being]]: An Essay on Locality'', [[Fordham University]] Press * 1984: ''[[Art]] and its Significance: an Anthology of [[Aesthetics|Aesthetic]] Theory'' (editor), SUNY Press; 2nd ed in 1987, 3rd ed in 1994 * 1983: ''Perspective in [[Alfred North Whitehead|Whitehead]]'s [[Metaphysics]]'', SUNY Press * 1982: ''A Theory of [[Art]]: Inexhaustibility by Contrast'', SUNY Press * 1981: ''[[Learning]] and [[Discovery (observation)|Discovery]]'', Gordon and Breach * 1981: ''[[Philosophy|Philosophical]] [[:wikt:mystery|Mysteries]]'', SUNY Press * 1980: ''Transition to an Ordinal [[Metaphysics]]'', SUNY Press * 1972: ''[[Moral]] Decision'', Freeman, Cooper & Co. * 1973: ''The Nature of [[Moral Responsibility]]'', [[Wayne State University]] Press * 1971: ''The [[Science|Scientific]] Process'', [[Martinus Nijhoff]] Press * 1969: ''[[Literature]] and [[Philosophy]]: An Analysis of the [[Philosophy|Philosophical]] [[Novel]]'', Appleton-Century-Crofts * 1966: ''The Meaning of [[Education]]'', [[Martinus Nijhoff]] Press

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Steve Fuller | residence = [[Coventry]], England | other_names = | image =Steve William Fuller 2011.jpg | image_size = | caption =Steve Fuller in 2011 | birth_name = Steve William Fuller | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1959|07|12}} | birth_place = New York City, New York, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | known = | occupation = Academic [[philosopher]] and [[sociologist]] | title = Auguste Comte Chair in Social Epistemology at the Department of sociology at [[University of Warwick]], England | spouse = | partner = | children = | relations = | website = [http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/sociology/staff/academicstaff/sfuller/ Home page] | footnotes = | employer = }}
'''Steve William Fuller''' (born 12 July 1959) is an American philosopher-sociologist in the field of [[science and technology studies]]. He has published in the areas of [[social epistemology]], [[academic freedom]], and the subjects of [[intelligent design]] and [[transhumanism]].
==Biography==
Fuller attended [[Regis High School (New York City)|Regis High School]] in [[Manhattan]].<ref>{{cite book|accessdate=4 August 2014|last=Fuller|first=Steve |title=Science vs. Religion? Intelligent Design and the Problem of Evolution |page=9|url= https://books.google.com/?id=1P22AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA9 |date= 2007|publisher=Polity Press|isbn=9780745673493}}</ref> Admitted as a John Jay Scholar to [[Columbia University]], he majored in History and Sociology and graduated ''summa cum laude'' in 1979. Awarded a [[Kellett Fellowship]], he studied at [[Clare College, Cambridge]], and received an M.Phil. in History and Philosophy of Science in 1981. He earned his Ph.D. in the same subject from the [[University of Pittsburgh]] in 1985, where he was an Andrew Mellon Pre-Doctoral Fellow. Fuller's doctoral dissertation, "Bounded Rationality in Law and Science", explored the implications of the views of [[Herbert A. Simon]] for political theory and philosophy of science.
Fuller held assistant and associate professorships at the [[University of Colorado at Boulder]], [[Virginia Tech]] and the [[University of Pittsburgh]]. In 1994, he was appointed to the chair in sociology and social policy at the [[University of Durham]], [[England]]. He moved in 1999 to the [[University of Warwick]], England. In July 2007 Fuller was awarded a [[D. Litt.]] by Warwick in recognition of "published work or papers which demonstrate a high standard of important original work forming a major contribution to a subject".<ref>[http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/insite/newsandevents/warwickpeople/higher_doctorates_for/ Higher Doctorates for Warwick People], [[University of Warwick]]</ref> In 2008, Fuller served as President of the Sociology section of the [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]]. In that capacity, he staged a play, "Lincoln and Darwin—Live for One Night Only!", at the BA's annual Festival of Science in Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=403503 |title=On stage, On the Origin ... author endures a dramatic trial of faith |publisher=Times Higher Education |date= |accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> The play was later produced as a podcast in Australia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sciphijournal.com/2009/02/11/11-darwin-and-lincoln-for-one-night-only/ |title=Lincoln and Darwin for one night only |publisher=Sci Phi Journal |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=1 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226215015/http://sciphijournal.com/2009/02/11/11-darwin-and-lincoln-for-one-night-only/ |archivedate=26 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Fuller has been a visiting professor in Denmark, Germany, Israel, Japan, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden (where he held a Fulbright Professorship in 1995 at Gothenburg University), and the United States (UCLA).<ref name="CV">{{cite web |url=http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/sociology/staff/academicstaff/sfuller/fullers_index/cv/ |title=curriculum vitae |publisher=.warwick.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=1 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022061915/http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/sociology/staff/academicstaff/sfuller/fullers_index/cv/ |archivedate=22 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2010 Fuller became a Senior Fellow at the Center for the Study of Interdisciplinarity at the University of North Texas. In 2011, the University of Warwick appointed him to the [[Auguste Comte]] Chair in Social Epistemology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/insite/newsandevents/warwickpeople/steve_fuller_social_epistemology/ |title=Professor Steve Fuller appointed to Auguste Comte Chair in Social Epistemology |publisher=.warwick.ac.uk |date=26 June 2012 |accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> In 2011, Fuller was appointed a Fellow of the UK [[Academy of Social Sciences]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/insite/news/warwickpeople/acss_three_awards |title=Academy of Social Sciences appoints three Warwick Academicians |publisher=.warwick.ac.uk |date=26 June 2012 |accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> In 2012, he was appointed to an Honorary Professorship at [[Dalian University of Technology]], China.<ref>[http://news.dlut.edu.cn/article/2012/0524/42609.shtml (in Chinese)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528165211/http://news.dlut.edu.cn/article/2012/0524/42609.shtml |date=28 May 2012 }}. News.dlut.edu.cn (24 May 2012). Retrieved on 14 May 2016.</ref> In 2012, he was made a member of the [[European Academy of Sciences and Arts]] in Division I (Humanities).<ref>[http://www.euro-acad.eu/members?filter=f&klass=&land=United+Kingdom&sort=class European Academy of Sciences and Arts]. Euro-acad.eu. Retrieved on 14 May 2016.</ref>
==Work== Fuller is most closely associated with [[social epistemology]] as an interdisciplinary research program. Social [[epistemology]] is a normative discipline that addresses philosophical problems of knowledge using the tools of history and the social sciences. Fuller founded the first journal (1987)<ref>http://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?show=editorialBoard&journalCode=tsep20#.VJ6H3V4gMA</ref> and wrote the first book (1988)<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fuller|first1=Steve|title=Philosophy, Rhetoric, and the end of knowledge|date=1993|publisher=The University of Wisconsin Press|page=xii}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=_-jJmvfREmQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Social+Epistemology%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=K4qeVPCNAo3sasbwgrAF&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Social%20Epistemology%22&f=false ]</ref> devoted to this topic. The most obvious feature of Fuller's approach, already present in his 1988 book, is that he rejects out of hand the Cartesian problem of [[scepticism]].
Along with 21 books, Fuller has written 65 book chapters, 155 academic articles and many minor pieces. He has given many distinguished lectures and plenary addresses, and has presented to academic and non-academic audiences throughout the world, including over 100 media interviews. His works have been translated into fifteen languages. 23 academic symposia have been published on his work. He moved to the [[United Kingdom]] in 1994, the year he organized a conference in Durham on "Science's Social Standing".<ref name="CV"/>
Since moving to the UK, Fuller has increasingly oriented himself towards public intellectual expression, including television, radio and internet, which he interprets as a natural outgrowth of his version of social epistemology. Two of his books have been recognised in this regard. ''[[Kuhn vs. Popper]]'' was Book of the Month for February 2005 in the US mass circulation magazine, ''Popular Science''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mone |first=Gregory |url=http://www.popsci.com/scitech/article/2005-02/not-quite-rumble-theoretical-jungle |title=(Not Quite a) Rumble in the Theoretical Jungle | Popular Science |publisher=Popsci.com |date=13 July 1965 |accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> However, [[Rupert Read]] wrote: "I did not have to read far into this book in order to conclude that it is worthless. ... In sum: this book offers only a cartoon opposition of a fake 'Popper' to a fake 'Kuhn.'"<ref name="2005Read">{{Cite journal | last = Read | first = Rupert | title = Book review: How and how not to write on a "legendary" philosopher | journal = [[Philosophy of the Social Sciences (journal)|Philosophy of the Social Sciences]] | volume = 35 | issue = 1 | pages = 369–387 | doi = 10.1177/0048393105279925 | date = September 2005 }}</ref> Fuller responded, coining the word "Kuhnenstein" (Kuhn + Wittgenstein) to capture Read's view of Kuhn, which Fuller calls a "figment of Read's – and other's – fertile imagination."<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Fuller | first = Steve | title = Kuhnenstein: or, the importance of being read | journal = [[Philosophy of the Social Sciences (journal)|Philosophy of the Social Sciences]] | volume = 35 | issue = 4 | pages = 480–498 | doi = 10.1177/0048393105280868 | date = December 2005 }}</ref> ''The Intellectual'' was selected as a Book of the Year in 2005 by the UK liberal-left magazine, ''New Statesman''. He periodically contributes a column to the Project Syndicate, associated with George Soros' Open Society project, which appears in several languages in newspapers across the world.<ref>[http://www.project-syndicate.org/search?search_string=Steve+Fuller&languageid=1&rm=search&submit=submit&submit.x=17&submit.y=13 Project Syndicate]. Project Syndicate. Retrieved on 14 May 2016.</ref> In 2006 he also taught a course on the epistemology of journalism at an international summer school at the [[University of Lund]], Sweden.<ref>[http://www.icomm.lu.se/summerschool/course1.html The Epistemology of Journalism Course Description] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061118133435/http://www.icomm.lu.se/summerschool/course1.html |date=18 November 2006 }}, [[University of Lund]]</ref>
===Academic freedom===
Fuller believes (modeled on what he takes to be the German model) that [[academic freedom]] is a freedom reserved for academics, not a special case of freedom of speech.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Fuller | first1 = Steve | last2 = Haworth | first2 = Alan | title = Academic freedom | journal = [[The Philosophers' Magazine]] | volume = 38 | issue = 2 | pages = 72–77 | doi = 10.5840/tpm20073864 | date = 2007 }} Debating the [http://www.afaf.org.uk/afaf-statement/ "statement of academic freedom"] made by Academics for Academic Freedom (AFAF).</ref> This includes the right to "cause reasoned offence", if within the terms of reason and evidence appropriate to the academic profession.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/higher/against-the-grain-it-is-an-academics-right-to-cause-reasoned-offence-455905.html | work=The Independent | location=London | title=Against the grain: It is an academic's right to cause 'reasoned' offence | first=Nick | last=Jackson | date=5 July 2007 | accessdate=24 May 2010}}</ref> He believes it important for academics to be able to express intellectual opinions for further debate which can result in progress. He also argues that students are equally entitled to academic freedom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=410297 |title=A clear and present danger |publisher=Times Higher Education |date= |accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref>
===Intelligent design=== Fuller has made many statements about his support for [[intelligent design]] (ID) and authored two books on the subject. In 2005, in the case of ''[[Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District]]'', he testified on behalf of a local school system in the United States that required the teaching of intelligent design. The decision of the U.S. District Court held that intelligent design was a form of [[creationism]] and that its inclusion in the curriculum violated the U.S. Constitution's prohibition on the [[Establishment Clause|establishment of religion]]. The decision repeatedly cited Fuller's testimony to undermine the school system's position. Some of Fuller's critics within the [[Science and Technology Studies]] community described his participation in the trial as "naive" and suggested that the field needs further development before it can constructively engage the legal community on the nature of science.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Lynch | first = Michael | author-link = Michael Lynch (ethnomethodologist) | title = From Ruse to Farce | journal = [[Social Studies of Science]] | volume = 36 | issue = 6 | pages = 819–826 | doi = 10.1177/0306312706067897 | date = December 2006 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Edmond | first1 = Gary | last2 = Mercer | first2 = David | title = Anti-social epistemologies | journal = [[Social Studies of Science]] | volume = 36 | issue = 6 | pages = 843–853 | doi = 10.1177/0306312706067900 | date = December 2006}}</ref>
Fuller has said that he does not support intelligent design "but feels that it should have a 'fair run for its money{{'"}}.<ref>{{cite news|last=Corbyn|first=Zoe|title=Steve Fuller: Designer trouble |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2006/jan/31/academicexperts.highereducationprofile|publisher=The Guardian |location=London|date=1 February 2006}}</ref> In his book ''Dissent over Descent'', he says he sees religion in general as a motivating influence in scientific pursuits and believes that the difference between science and religion is more institutional than intellectual.<ref>{{cite book|last=Fuller|first=Steve|title=Dissent Over Descent|year=2007|publisher=Icon|isbn=9781840468045|pages=8–9}}</ref><ref>[http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=200538&sectioncode=26 Schools for the Enlightenment or epiphany?: Steve Fuller], [[The Times Higher Education Supplement]], 25 December 2005</ref> Critics have called his views on science [[Postmodernism|postmodernist]], though others characterise them as more closely related to [[Social constructionism#Social constructionism and postmodernism|social constructionism]].<ref>[http://www2.ncseweb.org/kvd/all_legal/2005-10_amicus_briefs/2005-11-04_SciPolicy_Journal_amicus.pdf Brief for Amicus Curiae, Scipolicy Journal of Science and Health Policy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930204245/http://www2.ncseweb.org/kvd/all_legal/2005-10_amicus_briefs/2005-11-04_SciPolicy_Journal_amicus.pdf |date=30 September 2007 }}, ''Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District''</ref><ref>[http://www.talkreason.org/articles/Fuller.cfm Steve Fuller and The Hidden Agenda of Social Constructivism], Norman Levitt, Talk Reason</ref>
On 21 February 2007, Fuller debated [[Lewis Wolpert]] at [[Royal Holloway, University of London]] on whether evolution and intelligent design should be accorded equal status as scientific theories. Fuller supported the proposition. Fuller endorsed a work in support of Intelligent Design, the [[Discovery Institute]]'s textbook ''[[Explore Evolution: The Arguments For and Against Neo-Darwinism]]'' (2007).<ref>[http://exploreevolution.com/endorsements.php Endorsements], [[Explore Evolution: The Arguments For and Against Neo-Darwinism|Explore Evolution]] website</ref>
Appearing in the 2008 film ''[[Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed]]'', Fuller told an interviewer:<ref name=expelled>''Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed'' (2008 film). Rocky Mountain Pictures. Directed by Nathan Frankowski.</ref> {{quote|If you take seriously that evolution has to do with the transition of life forms, and that life and death are just natural processes, then one gets to be liberal about abortion and euthanasia. All of those kinds of ideas seem to me follow very naturally from a Darwinian perspective – a deprivileging of human beings, basically. And I think people who want to endorse Darwinism have to take this kind of viewpoint very seriously.}}
Fuller openly acknowledges that while some people simply do not like or accept either 'design in nature' or that human beings were created "in the image and likeness of God" (''imago Dei''), many people do and that it has been a consistent fixture in the progress, development and motivation for doing modern science.<ref>{{cite video| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_zQ51gVtJAw | first=Steve | last=Fuller |title="Why some people like the idea of design in nature and others don't" |work=University of Cambridge, |date=14 July 2012 |accessdate= 19 April 2015}}</ref>
===Transhumanism=== Much of his work focuses on questions around technological enhancements and how they can improve the capacities of human beings.<ref>[http://ieet.org/index.php/IEET/bio/fuller/ Steve Fuller]. Ieet.org. Retrieved on 14 May 2016.</ref> Fuller argues that the pursuit for enhancements is based on a need ″to create some distance between ourselves and the other animals.″ <ref>{{cite news | first=Kevin | last=Holmes | title = Talking to the future humans – Steve Fuller | url= https://www.vice.com/en_uk/read/talking-to-the-future-humans-steve-fuller-transhumanism | work=Vice Media | date= 29 September 2011 | accessdate= 15 February 2015 }}</ref> For Fuller, transhumanism offers humanity the prospect "to re-engineer the human body to enable us to live longer so as to work and play harder." <ref>{{cite book|last=Fuller|first=Steve|title=Humanity 2.0|year=2011|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9780230233423|page=242}}</ref>
He featured in the 2016 documentary [[The Future of Work and Death]]. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2017/mar/03/no-more-death-taxes-but-do-we-really-want-to-live-forever-with-nothing-to-do|title=No more 'death & taxes' – but do we really want to live forever with nothing to do?|last=Beard|first=Matthew|date=2017-03-02|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
==Principal works==
===''Science Vs Religion?''=== In 2007, Fuller wrote ''Science Vs Religion?: Intelligent Design and the Problem of Evolution''. In addition to introductory and conclusionary chapters, it has chapters on the history of the [[relationship between religion and science]], the thesis that modern science has its basis in an attempt by humanity to transcend itself and reach God, how Fuller believes complexity distinguishes ID from "other versions of creationism", legal issues, and the future of "[[Darwinism]]".<ref name=Sarkar>[http://ndpr.nd.edu/review.cfm?id=13887 Review of ''Science Vs Religion?''], Sahotra Sarkar, ''Notre Dame Philosophical Reviews'', 7 August 2008</ref>
Professor of mathematics at [[Rutgers University]], [[Norman Levitt]] in a review described it as "a truly miserable piece of work, crammed with errors scientific, historical, and even theological".<ref name="2007Levitt">{{cite news | url=http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/07-12-19.html#feature | title=Norman Levitt Deconstructs Steve Fuller's Postmodernist Critique of Evolution | publisher=[[Skeptic (U.S. magazine)]] |date=19 December 2007 | first=Norman | last= Levitt | accessdate =10 October 2008 }}</ref> Levitt took issue with the following points:<ref name="2007Levitt"/> *Fuller's acceptance at face value of [[William Dembski]]'s claims on complexity and randomness, and his failure to come to grips with the wealth of results that this field has generated and with the trenchant criticism of Dembski's claims (or even to describe these claims accurately); *Fuller's disparagement of [[evolutionary biology]], without doing "serious analysis of the working methods and logical structure of biology itself" on which to base it; *Fuller's misrepresentation of [[Isaac Newton]]'s religious beliefs in order to make a point that is in fact antithetical to Newton's views; Levitt infers that Fuller's views arise from an "animosity to science as such and to its cognitive authority [that] still pervades academic life outside the dominion of the science faculty".<ref>[http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/07-12-19.html#feature The Painful Elaboration of the Fatuous], Norman Levitt, eSkeptic, [[Skeptic (U.S. magazine)|Skeptic magazine]]</ref> Fuller later responded to these points, accusing Levitt of axe-grinding and questioning his understanding of the book, which Fuller claimed was less a defense of contemporary intelligent design theory than a demonstration of its rootedness in the history of science. Fuller also claims that Levitt misquotes one of the three passages Levitt cites from the book, making it mean the opposite of the original.<ref>[http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/08-01-16.html#feature Steve Fuller Responds to Norman Levitt's Review of ''Science v. Religion''] E-Skeptic, 16 January 2008</ref> Levitt subsequently responded at length to Fuller, concluding that "Fuller's misreading of the politics that generated and sustains the ID movement is so complete as to constitute a peculiar pathology all its own."<ref>[http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/08-01-23.html#response Norman Levitt Responds to Steve Fuller] E-Skeptic, 23 January 2008</ref> Fuller has long been highly critical of the views of science of his opponents in the [[Science Wars]], including Levitt, dating back at least to 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=154395&sectioncode=26|title=In Snow's shoes |publisher=THES|date=11 November 1994|accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref><ref>''Can Science Studies be Spoken in a Civil Tongue?'', S Fuller, Social Studies of Science, 1994</ref>
[[Sahotra Sarkar]], a philosophy professor<ref>[http://www.utexas.edu/cola/depts/philosophy/faculty/profiles/Sarkar/Sahotra/ Sahotra Sarkar] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20051215051045/http://www.utexas.edu/cola/depts/philosophy/faculty/profiles/Sarkar/Sahotra/ |date=15 December 2005 }}, Department of Philosophy, [[University of Texas]]</ref> and integrative biologist<ref>[http://www.biosci.utexas.edu/ib/faculty/indexb.html Faculty], Section of Integrative Biology, [[University of Texas]]</ref> at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] also criticised Fuller's book for presenting an "analysis of the intellectual disputes over contemporary ID creationism [that] is almost vacuous".<ref name="2008Sarkar">{{cite news | url=http://ndpr.nd.edu/review.cfm?id=13887 | title=Science v. Religion? Intelligent Design and the Problem of Evolution | publisher=Philosophical Reviews |date=7 August 2008 | first=Norman | last= Levitt | accessdate =10 October 2008 }}</ref> Sarkar further states that the book has an idiosyncratic interpretation of the [[history of philosophy]], including of [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]], and of [[logical positivism]]; having a limited grasp of the [[history of science]], including making claims about [[Isaac Newton|Newton]], [[Georges Cuvier|Cuvier]], [[Louis Agassiz|Agassiz]], [[Lamarck]], [[Gregor Mendel|Mendel]], Pearson and [[Galton]] that are not supported by their writings; failure to engage the "debate over naturalism that ID creationism has generated" with "remarks on supernaturalism [that show] him to be equally non-cognizant of the work of ... Philip Johnson"; and other scientific errors.<ref name="2008Sarkar"/>
===''Dissent Over Descent''=== In 2008 Fuller's book on the intelligent design controversy, ''Dissent Over Descent: Intelligent Design's Challenge to Darwinism'' was published. Steven Poole of [[The Guardian]] wrote: "book is an epoch-hopping parade of straw men, incompetent reasoning and outright gibberish, as when evolution is argued to share with astrology a commitment to "action at a distance", except that the distance is in time rather than space. It's intellectual quackery like this that gives philosophy of science a bad name."<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2008/jul/12/saturdayreviewsfeatres.guardianreview7 | title=Trivial pursuits Steve Fuller's Dissent Over Descent: Intelligent Design's Challenge to Darwinism | publisher=The Guardian |date=12 July 2008 | first=Steven | last=Poole | accessdate =10 October 2008 | location=London}}</ref> [[Michael Ruse]], Philosopher of Science at [[Florida State University]] wrote in the journal ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' that Fuller's book "is completely wrong and is backed by no sound scholarship whatsoever. In at least one case, Fuller makes his case by an egregious misreading—of something I wrote about the role of genetic drift in Sewall Wright's shifting balance theory. For the record, Charles Darwin set out to provide a cause, what he called—following his mentors like William Whewell (who in turn referred back to Newton)—a true cause or ''vera causa''. Darwin felt, and historians and philosophers of science as well as practicing evolutionary biologists still feel, that he succeeded…"<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/reprint/322/5898/47.pdf |format=PDF| title=A Challenge Standing on Shaky Clay | publisher=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |date=3 October 2008 | first=Michael | last=Ruse | accessdate =10 October 2008 }}</ref> In a "book of the week" review by retired Divinity Professor [[Keith Ward]] in the ''[[Times Higher Education Supplement]],'' the book was praised for providing often overlooked information and provocative interpretations, but was criticised for a number of inaccuracies and misrepresentations.<ref>[http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=402929 The book of the week: Dissent over Descent], [[Times Higher Education Supplement]], 24 July 2008</ref>
[[A. C. Grayling]], in [[New Humanist]], wrote that the book contains a "mark of ignorance and historical short-sightedness on Fuller's part".<ref name="2008NewHumanist">{{cite web | url=http://newhumanist.org.uk/1856| title=Origin of the specious | publisher=[[New Humanist]] |date=September 2008 | first=A.C. | last= Grayling | accessdate =10 October 2008 }}</ref> In response, Fuller wrote an online response saying "if Grayling's grasp of the history of science went beyond head-banging standards, he would realise that our current level of scientific achievement would never have been reached, and more importantly that we would not be striving to achieve more, had chance-based explanations dominated over the design-based ones in our thinking about reality."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://newhumanist.org.uk/1880 | title=Against the faith | publisher=[[New Humanist]] |date=September 2008 | first=Steve | last=Fuller | accessdate =10 October 2008 }}</ref> To which Grayling wrote: "Steve Fuller complains, as do all authors whose books are panned, that I did not read his book properly (or at all)."<ref name="2008NewHumanistWeb">{{cite news | url=http://newhumanist.org.uk/1881 | title=Bolus of nonsense| publisher=[[New Humanist]] |date=September 2008 | first=A.C. | last= Grayling | accessdate =10 October 2008 }}</ref> He continued, "I'll take on Fuller any day regarding the history and theology of the various versions of Christianity with which humanity has been burdened. […] The same applies to the history of science."<ref name="2008NewHumanistWeb"/>

{{multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=January 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=May 2018}} }} '''Supererogation''' ([[Latin|Late Latin]]: ''supererogatio'' "payment beyond what is due or asked", from ''super'' "beyond" and ''erogare'' "to pay out, expend", itself from ''ex'' "out" and ''rogare'' "to ask") is the performance of more than is asked for; the action of doing more than [[duty]] requires. In [[ethics]], an act is '''supererogatory''' if it is good but not morally required to be done. It refers to an act that is more than is necessary, when another course of action—involving less—would still be an acceptable action. It differs from a duty, which is an act wrong not to do, and from acts morally neutral. Supererogation may be considered as performing above and beyond a normative course of duty to further benefits and functionality. ==In Catholicism== In the [[theology]] of the [[Roman Catholic Church]], "works of supererogation" (also called "acts of supererogation") are those performed beyond what God requires. For example, in [[1 Corinthians 7]], [[Paul the Apostle]] says that while everyone is free to marry, it is better to refrain from marriage and remain celibate to better serve God. The Roman Catholic Church holds that the [[counsels of perfection]] are supererogatory acts, which specific [[Christian]]s may engage in above their moral duties. Similarly, it teaches that to determine how to act, one must engage in reasonable efforts to be sure of what the right actions are; after the reasonable action, the person is in a state of [[vincible ignorance|invincible ignorance]] and guiltless of wrongdoing, but to undertake more than reasonable actions to overcome ignorance is supererogatory, and praiseworthy. According to the classic teaching on [[indulgence]]s, the works of supererogation performed by all the saints form a treasure with God, the "[[treasury of merit,]]" which the church can apply to exempt [[repentance (Christianity)|repentant]] sinners from the works of [[penance|penitence]] that would otherwise be required of them to achieve full reconciliation with the church. ==In Protestantism== [[Martin Luther]]'s opposition of this teaching seeded the [[Protestant Reformation]]. The [[Church of England]] denied the doctrine of supererogation in the fourteenth of the [[Thirty-Nine Articles]], which states that works of supererogation
cannot be taught without arrogancy and impiety: for by them men do declare, that they not only render unto God as much as they are bound to, but that they do more for his sake, than of bounden duty is required: whereas Christ saith plainly, When ye have done all that are commanded to you, say, We are unprofitable servants[https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer_(ECUSA)/Historical_Documents_of_the_Church/Articles_of_Religion Book of Common Prayer (ECUSA)/Historical Documents of the Church/Articles of Religion. XIV. Of Works of Supererogation.]
Later Protestant movements followed suit, such as in the [[Methodism|Methodist]] [[Articles of Religion (Methodist)|Articles of Religion]].[http://www.umc.org/what-we-believe/the-articles-of-religion-of-the-methodist-church The Methodist Articles of Religion/Doctrinal Standards of The United Methodist Church/Articles of Religion. XI. Of Works of Supererogation.] ==In Islam== A [[Muslim]] must complete a minimum of the [[Salah#The Five Daily Prayers|five daily prayers]], each typically lasting an average of 5 to 10 minutes. Supererogatory prayers beyond these are known as [[Nafl prayer|nafl]] prayers, and praying them is considered to bear additional reward. There are also several other supererogatory acts in [[Islam]], such as fasting outside of the month of [[Ramadhan]], or giving [[sadaqah]] (charity, consisting of simple acts of kindness to financial assistance) that is not obligatory. ==Discussion== Whether an act is supererogatory or obligatory can be debated. In many schools of thought, donating money to [[Charitable organization|charity]] is supererogatory. In other schools of thought that regard some level of charitable donation to be duty (such as with the [[tithe]] in [[Judaism]], [[zakat]] in Islam, and similar standards in many Christian sects), only exceeding a certain level of donation (e.g. going above the common 2.5%-of-capital-assets standard in zakat) would count as supererogatory. In [[criminal law]], it may be observed that state prohibitions on killing, stealing, and so on derive from the state's duty to protect one's own citizens. However, a nation state has no duty to protect the citizens of an adjacent nation from crime. To send a [[peacekeeping]] force into another country would be — in the view of the nation doing it — supererogatory. Some schools of ethics do not include supererogatory acts. In [[utilitarianism]], an act can only be better because it would bring more good to a greater number, and in that case it becomes a duty, not a supererogatory act. The lack of a notion of supererogation in utilitarianism and related schools leads to the [[demandingness objection]], arguing that these schools are too ethically demanding, requiring unreasonable acts. ==References== {{Reflist}} * {{EB1911|title=Supererogation}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary|supererogation|supererogatory}} {{wikiquote}} * {{SEP|supererogation|Supererogation|David Heyd|October 5, 2015}} [[Category:Religious ethics]] [[Category:Methodism]] [[Category:Anglicanism]] [[Category:Catholic theology and doctrine]] [[Category:Christian terminology]] [[Category:Concepts in ethics]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''The Eighth Day'' (bioethics book)}} '''''The Eighth Day''''' is the second book of Dr. [[Euler Renato Westphal]], originally published in Portuguese with the title '''''O Oitavo Dia: Na era da seleção natural'''''.
In the second book of Dr. Euler Westphal, professor of [[Systematic Theology]] and Ethical Issues, the Brazilian researcher analyses the scientific and technological advancement to propose a multidisciplinary dialogue about [[bioethics]].<ref>Termo casamento não cabe na relação homossexual http://elistas.alcnoticias.org/lista/portugues_alc/archivo/indice/921/msg/881/</ref>
This book is at the basis of the curriculum of the Interdisciplinarity Seminarium of the Lutheran School of Theology in São Bento do Sul, Brazil.<ref>Curriculum of Euler Westphal http://buscatextual.cnpq.br/buscatextual/visualizacv.jsp?id=K4796349P9&tipo=completo&idiomaExibicao=1 / FLT Curriculum http://www.flt.edu.br/bacharelado/Grade%20Curricular%20Curso%20de%20Teologia.pdf</ref> It's also an important book in the discussion of the Theology as a science, and its relationship with other sciences particularly Biology, and Philosophical Ethics.<ref>Rudolph von Sinner. Teologia como ciência. http://www3.est.edu.br/publicacoes/estudos_teologicos/vol4702_2007/ET2007-2d_rvsinner.pdf / Derval Dasílio. RETORNEMOS AO PASTOR QUE APASCENTA A VIDA. http://derv.wordpress.com/page/3/</ref>
He finds on the post-modern thinking and its concepts of performativity, utility, and lucrativity, and the [[Bauhaus]] model of bricolage a new scientific paradigm. The post-modern paradigm broke with the modern paradigm of rationality.<ref>WESTPHAL, Euler R. O Oitavo Dia: Na era da seleção natural, pages 5ff.</ref>
The [[post-modernism]] look at the nature as a good thing when it is useful to the humankind, because science and human power are coincident. In the post-modern religion the eschatological and messianic hope is no more in Jesus Christ, but in the efforts to find out a possibility to immortality, good wealth and eternal life through genetical improvement. The wishes of the post-modern man are to reach the perfect human being, the great wealth, without illness and death, the [[brave new world]].<ref>Id. Ibid, pages 20ff.</ref>
When science becomes religion and the scientists become priests the humankind starts a new age of totalitarianism of science. The reality of the Almighty God, Creator and Redeemer, is no more recognized by post-modern man, who now adopt the performativity and lucrativity as a new dogma of scientific religion. [[Predestination]] is no more a Christian dogma but a concept of biotechnology. The scientist can see, as a small-great-god, who is predestined by the genetic code to develop an illness, like a cancer. Therefore, the scientist became the one who can choose life or death for a new life under formation.<ref>Id. Ibid, pages 40ff.</ref> 88 There are many risks on see the science as a religion. Or to put the science as criteria of truth, specially this kind of science that has on post-modern thinking its epistemological base. The practice of get patents of living being its one of these kinds of risks. When an economical group has the patent of a soy bean, than the farmers cannot produce soy without pay royalties to the company that has the patent rights. So poor people at south countries will have their free access to seeds for planting not allowed, in consequence they will not have food for their countries.<ref>Id. Ibid, pages 60ff.</ref>
The bioethics is multidisciplinary subject, it dialogues with different ethical issues like philosophical ethics, medical ethics, theological ethics and so one. [[Theology]] can give its contribution on situations like abort, euthanasia, research with living beings. The Christian faith can recover the respect with life and its mystery.<ref>Id. Ibid, pages 80ff.</ref>
In the Eighth Day the human being has created the brave new world. The little-man-god redesigned the life beings and the human being as image and likeness of the Market-God's utilitarists interests. We need to give the appropriate place to the creation and to the human beings as creation of the Triune God. All things are maintained by the presence of His Holy Spirit. Humility of the science will guarantee that science still be science and not became a religion that promise eternal life, immortality and salvation.<ref>Id. Ibid, pages 110ff.</ref>

{{Cleanup-rewrite|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox organization | name = Tres Dias | type = Faith-based | image = TD Intl.jpg | founded_date = 1972 | founder = Dave McManigal | area_served = International | focus = Christian Servant Leadership Training | method = Direct aid
Program funding | homepage = {{URL|http://tresdias.org/}} }} '''Tres Dias''' is a Christian [[Interdenominationalism|interdenominational]] [[three-day movement]] which aims to concentrate closely on the person and teachings of Jesus Christ. In 1985 Tres Dias became an international organization when communities were chartered in [[Korea]] and [[Germany]]. Tres Dias' global reach now includes [[Denmark]], [[Peru]], [[Ireland]], [[Canada]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Ukraine]], and [[Russia]]. ==Tres Dias Con Dios== In 2012, Tres Dias launched its Spanish-speaking set of weekends - called Tres Dias Con Dios. Normally conducted in English, if hosted in the United States, Tres Dias con Dios is conducted entirely in Spanish throughout the three-day event. The first [[Tres Dias Con Dios]] weekend was held in Southeast TN, called Southeast TN Tres Dias con Dios—Three Days with God. ==Brand identity== In 2015, Tres Dias launched its new website featuring testimonials from community members across the globe, updated newsletters, and blog postings. In January 2016, Tres Dias announced a new marketing program called "Millennial Reach". The majority of Tres Dias weekend attendees have been between the ages of 45-85. In an effort to reach a younger attendee audience, Tres Dias launched its largest social media marketing plan in its history to date. ==New communities== The list of new Tres Dias communities include: * [[www.alamocitytresdias.org|Alamo City Tres Dias]] * [[www.brazosvalleytresdias.org|Brazos Valley Tres Dias]] * [[www.centraltexastresdias.org|Central Texas Tres Dias]] * [[www.ettd.org|East Texas Tres Dias]] * [[www.etvidanueva.com|East Texas Vida Nueva]] * [[www.heartoftexastresdias.com|Heart of Texas Tres Dias]] * [[www.ggctd.org|Grace Gulf Coast Tres Dias]] * [[www.nttd.org|North Texas Tres Dias]] * [[www.northeasttexastresdias.com|North East Texas Tres Dias]] * [[www.settd.org|South East Texas Tres Dias]] * [[www.setvn.org|South East Texas Vida Nueva]] * [[www.trinityvalleytresdias.org|Trinity Valley Tres Dias]] * [[www.nwartd.org|Northwest Arkansas Tres Dias]] * Montego Bay Tres Dias * [[Kansas City Tres Dias]]{{cite web|last=Stultz|first=Samantha|url=http://kctd.org|title=Kansas City Tres Dias|accessdate=23 January 2012}}
Website http://www.kctd.org * Tres Dias Denmark{{cite web|title=List of Tres Dias Communities|url=http://tresdias.org/hp.htm|accessdate=23 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210132842/http://tresdias.org/hp.htm|archivedate=10 February 2012|df=}} * Treasure Valley Tres Dias * Southern New Jersey Tres Dias * Orange County Tres Dias * Northern California Tres Dias * Lehigh Valley Tres Dias * Agua Viva Tres Dias[http://www.tresdias.org/Miscel/History/history.htm History of the Tres Dias Movement] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080310070540/http://www.tresdias.org/Miscel/History/history.htm |date=2008-03-10 }} * Northwest Arkansas Tres Dias * Perú Tres Dias Lima * [https://www.tresdias-mt.org/ Montana Tres Dias] ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.tresdias.org Tres Dias International Official Website] * [http://www.tdkr.org Tres Dias Korean Region Committee Website (Korean)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031013/http://www.cts.tv/news/news_view.asp?PID=P368&DPID=141319 33rd Tres Dias International in Seoul, Korea (CTS-TV, Christian Television Service Korea), September 14, 2012 News)] [[Category:Christian parachurch organizations]] [[Category:Spiritual retreats]]

revision.text:
'''Use-of-force law in Missouri''' refers to the law & [[legal doctrine]] which determine whether a member of law enforcement in the state of Missouri is justified in the amount of force used to gain control of an unruly situation or person, including situations involving death. In the [[United States]], doctrine about use of force is primarily defined by the individual states, although there have been some [[Use of force|Supreme Court decisions]] of limited scope.
[[Missouri|Missouri's]] legal experts have said the use of force laws in Missouri are considered more officer-friendly than that in other states.<ref name=WSJFerguson>{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Ashby|title=Why Ferguson Officer Wasn't Charged: A Look at 'Use of Force' Doctrine|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2014/11/24/why-ferguson-officer-wasnt-charged-a-look-at-use-of-force-doctrine/|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=Wall Street Journal (Law Blog)|date=November 24, 2014}}</ref> Such laws have come under national scrutiny in the wake of the [[shooting of Michael Brown]] in 2014.<ref name=CBSAfterFergusson>{{cite news|last1=Condon|first1=Stephen|title=After Ferguson, can the use of force by police be addressed?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/after-ferguson-what-can-be-done-about-the-use-of-force-by-police/|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=CBS News|date=November 25, 2014}}</ref>
Current law governing use of force is specified in Missouri Revised Statutes chapter 563,<ref name=563.046.2>Missouri General Assembly (1977). "[http://www.moga.mo.gov/mostatutes/stathtml/56300000462.html L. S.B. 60 Effective 1-01-79—Law enforcement officer's use of force in making an arrest]". Missouri Revised Statutes Ch. 563 Defense of Justification § 046 r. 2.</ref> which differ substantially from the laws of neighboring states.<ref>{{cite web |last=Keefe |first=Brendan |date=November 11, 2014 |title=Deadly force laws different on each side of Mississippi |publisher=KSDK |accessdate=December 19, 2014 |url=http://www.ksdk.com/story/news/local/2014/11/12/deadly-force-laws-different-mississippi-missouri-illinois/18898855/}}</ref>
== Background ==
=== Use of force === {{main|Use of force}} In the course of their duties, law enforcement personnel use force to subdue suspects. The use of force consists of two parts: the amount of force that may lawfully be used on a [[Use of force continuum|continuum]] that includes [[deadly force]]; and the circumstances under which it may be used, including the level of imminent threat reasonably perceived by the member of law enforcement and the concern that a [[Fleeing felon rule|fleeing felon]] may harm the public.<ref name=DEADLYFORCEUSATODAY>{{cite news|last1=Keefe|first1=Brendan|title=Ferguson shooting highlights deadly force laws|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/11/12/deadly-force-laws-missouri-illinois/18919563/|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=USA Today|date=November 12, 2014}}</ref> Doctrines are intended to balance security needs with ethical concerns for the rights and well-being of intruders or suspects. In the event that members of the public are injured, this may give rise to issues of [[self-defense (theory)|self-defense]] as a [[excuse|justification]].<ref name=NYTWhatHappened>{{cite news|last1=Buchanan|first1=Larry|author9=Ford Fessenden|author2=K.K. Rebecca Lai|author3=Haeyoun Park|author4=Alicia Parlapiano|author5=Archie Tse|author6=Tim Wallace|author7=Derek Watkins|author8=Karen Yourish|title=What Happened in Ferguson?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/08/13/us/ferguson-missouri-town-under-siege-after-police-shooting.html?_r=0|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=New York Times|date=November 25, 2014}}</ref> In the event of death during a reasonable use of force, this may be legally considered a [[justifiable homicide]]. The application of excessive force is considered [[Police brutality]].<ref name=ABA>{{cite news|last1=Cassens Weiss|first1=Debra|title=Missouri's 'officer-friendly' use-of-force law likely helped Ferguson officer avoid charges|url=http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/missouris_officer_friendly_use_of_force_doctrine_likely_helped_ferguson_off|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=ABA Journal|publisher=American Bar Association|date=November 25, 2014}}</ref>
=== Use of force national guidelines === [[State police (United States)|State police in the United States]] are generally given considerable leeway in making the decision about the amount of force needed to save themselves or others. While there is no national definition, the [[United States Supreme Court]] has created legal standards for use of force through two key decisions. "Objective reasonableness" is a concept from the 1985 ''[[Tennessee v. Garner]]'' decision that stated that police officers could not shoot at a fleeing suspect simply to prevent their escape but only if the suspect posed a significant threat of death or serious harm to the community.<ref name=WPuseofforce>{{cite news|last1=Leonnig|first1=Carol D.|title=Current law gives police wide latitude to use deadly force|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/current-law-gives-police-wide-latitude-to-use-deadly-force/2014/08/28/768090c4-2d64-11e4-994d-202962a9150c_story.html|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=Washington Post|date=August 28, 2014}}</ref> In the 1989 decision of ''[[Graham v. Connor]]'', the court ruled that "the reasonableness of a particular use of force must be judged from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, and its calculus must embody an allowance for the fact that police officers are often forced to make split-second decisions about the amount of force necessary in a particular situation." <ref name=SentUseofFoce>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Joe|title=Use of force: What does the law say?|url=http://hanfordsentinel.com/news/local/crime/use-of-force-what-does-the-law-say/article_04a4ad69-7dd5-5099-a1e8-e764ab26c9b2.html|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=The Sentinel|date=July 28, 2014}}</ref> Current local and state doctrines vary in defining these decisions and are tested in civil lawsuits and criminal prosecutions on a case-by-case basis.<ref name=posthowgrandjury>{{cite news|last1=Kindy|first1=Kimberly|title=How the Ferguson grand jury process works|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/how-the-ferguson-grand-jury-process-works/2014/11/24/46599f9a-73f9-11e4-a589-1b102c2f81d0_story.html|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=Washington Post|date=November 24, 2014}}</ref> If a case where the use of force has been applied unevenly based on a suspect's race, sex, disability, religion, or national origin, the [[United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division|Civil Rights Division of the United States Department of Justice]] is empowered to bring charges for breaking [[Federal law]] governing [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]].<ref name=FedChargesCBS>{{cite news|last1=Staff writer|title=Feds launch investigation into Ferguson police department|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ferguson-missouri-shooting-feds-launch-investigation-into-police-department/|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=CBS News|agency=The Associated Press|date=September 4, 2014}}</ref><ref name=NPRfederal>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Carrie|title=Federal Ferguson Investigation Will Remain Independent, Holder Insists|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/itsallpolitics/2014/11/25/366527106/federal-ferguson-investigation-will-remain-independent-holder-insists|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=NPR: National Public Radio|date=November 25, 2014}}</ref> When the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] investigates a pattern of use of force abuses, it can work with a state or agency to create new policies that align with national law and precedent.<ref name=Reuters>{{cite news|last1=Cavaliere|first1=Victoria|title=Seattle police file federal lawsuit over 'use of force' policy|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/29/us-usa-washington-police-idUSKBN0E90AI20140529|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=Reuters|date=May 29, 2014}}</ref>
== Missouri doctrine == {{section or|date=December 2014}} [[List of law enforcement agencies in Missouri|Law enforcement agencies in Missouri]] exist at the town, county, and state levels and are subject to national guidelines, state laws, and applicable local or county policies. Use of force doctrine is defined in Missouri by state law as well as local policy.<ref name=WSJFerguson /> From the 1860s, when Missouri became a state, until the 1960s, individual states wrote their own codes, often using [[common law]] as a basis. In 1962, the [[Model Penal Code]] was published with recommendations to modernize and standardize penal law and [[criminal law of the United States|criminal law]] nationally.<ref name=MPC>[[Sanford H. Kadish]], "Codifiers of the Criminal Law: Wechsler's Predecessors", 78 ''[[Columbia Law Review]]'' 1098 (v.78, n.5, June 1978) and Monrad G. Paulsen and [[Sanford H. Kadish]], "Criminal Law and Its Processes" , 77 ''[[Harvard Law Review]]'' 790 (v.77, n.4, February 1964)</ref> The code served and continues to serve as a basis for the replacement of existing criminal codes in over two-thirds of the states.<ref>{{cite web|title=Criminal Law Basics|url=http://www.mojolaw.com/info/cl014|publisher=Mojo Law|accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> Missouri did not incorporate the recommendations.<ref name=KentLaw>{{cite journal|last1=Popek|first1=Karen A.|title=Unconstitutional Use of Deadly Force by the Police, The|journal=Chicago-Kent Law Review|date=January 1979|volume=55|issue=2|url=http://scholarship.kentlaw.iit.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2327&context=cklawreview|accessdate=25 November 2014|publisher=IIT Chicago-Kent College of Law}}</ref> The statutes concerning use of force in Missouri included the stipulation that police officers could use deadly force to stop a fleeing suspect of a felony including the event that the felony was not of a violent nature, such as a crime against property. In 1977, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit]] struck down these statutes in ''Mattis v. R Schnarr''.<ref>{{cite web| authorlink = [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit]]|title = 547 F. 2d 1007 - Mattis v. R Schnarr|publisher = United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit| date = December 1, 1976| url = http://openjurist.org/547/f2d/1007/mattis-v-r-schnarr | accessdate = 2013-06-12}}</ref> The court found that the Missouri statute authorizing the use of deadly force by police attempting to arrest any fleeing felon was unconstitutional as "an arbitrary imposition of death" and violation of [[due process]].<ref name=KentLaw />
In ''Tennessee v. Garner'', Justice [[Byron White|White]] wrote for the [[Majority opinion]] addressing the legal issue as whether the totality of the circumstances justified the deadly force. Because it deprives the suspect of his life, White concluded that deadly force should be applied only when there is a "[[reasonable suspicion]]" that a suspect is armed or dangerous. The legal concept derives from a prior decision in ''[[Terry v. Ohio]]'' (1968) where court recognized law enforcement's right to stop a possible suspect for a brief time and take additional steps to investigate further.<ref> For the Court in ''[[Berkemer v. McCarty]]'' 468 U.S. 420 (1984), [[Thurgood Marshall|Justice Marshall]] wrote :"the usual traffic stop is more analogous to a so-called '''Terry'' stop,' see ''Terry v. Ohio'', 392 U.S. 1 (1968)" (468 U.S. at 439)</ref> In 1989, Graham v. Connor, a similar finding was held; ""the reasonableness of a particular use of force must be judged from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, and its calculus must embody an allowance for the fact that police officers are often forced to make split-second decisions about the amount of force necessary in a particular situation."<ref name=SentUseofFoce /> Although Missouri statute still stated that law enforcement could use force including deadly force on any suspect that "has attempted to commit or has committed a felony," the concept of reasonableness was included.<ref name=STLouisNPR>{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Darren|author2=Chad Flanders|title=Missouri's Use Of Force Statute Goes Against Constitutional Rulings|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/commentary-missouris-use-force-statute-goes-against-constitutional-rulings|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=St Louis Public Radio|agency=National Public Radio|date=August 25, 2014}}</ref> "...An officer may only use deadly force as permitted by other justifications such a self defense or when he reasonably believes that such use of deadly force is immediately necessary to effect the arrest and also reasonably believes that the person to be arrested a)Has committed or attempted to commit a felony; or b) Is attempting to escape by use of a deadly weapon; or c) May otherwise endanger life or inflict serious physical injury unless arrested without delay."<ref name=mainevmissouri>{{cite news|last1=Rioux|first1=Luke|title=Missouri and Maine police use of force laws: when is deadly force justified?|url=http://contributors.pressherald.com/news/harmless-error/missouri-maine-police-use-force-laws/|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=The Press-Herald|agency=Maine Free Press|date=November 23, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Stlousipost>{{cite news|last1=Staff reports|title=Darren Wilson said fight at car justified use of force against Michael Brown|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/wilson-said-fight-at-car-justified-use-of-force/article_95453075-8661-5e47-ae35-94783d620c6e.html|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=November 25, 2014}}</ref>
Investigation into possible use of force violation is first conducted internally. A state prosecutor can also apply to judge or [[grand jury]] to decide whether there is enough evidence to pursue a prosecution.<ref name=BBCGrandjury>{{cite web|last1=Staff writer|title=Michael Brown: The workings of the grand jury explained|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-30042638|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=25 November 2014|date=November 24, 2014}}</ref> The application of the standard is interpreted by a jury in criminal cases.<ref name=WPuseofforce />
==See also== * [[Police accountability]]

revision.text: The '''volunteer's dilemma''' [[game theory|game]] models a situation in which each of X players faces the decision of either making a small sacrifice from which all will benefit, or [[free rider problem|freeriding]]. One example is a scenario in which the electricity has gone out for an entire neighborhood. All inhabitants know that the electricity company will fix the problem as long as at least one person calls to notify them, at some cost. If no one volunteers, the worst possible outcome is obtained for all participants. If any one person elects to volunteer, the rest benefit by not doing so.{{cite book |first=William |last=Poundstone |title=Prisoner's Dilemma: John von Neumann, Game Theory, and the Puzzle of the Bomb |year=1993 |location=New York |publisher=Anchor Books |isbn=0-385-41580-X }} A [[public good]] is only produced if at least one person volunteers to pay an arbitrary cost. In this game, bystanders decide independently on whether to sacrifice themselves for the benefit of the group. Because the volunteer receives no benefit, there is a greater incentive for freeriding than to sacrifice oneself for the group. If no one volunteers, everyone loses. The social phenomena of the [[bystander effect]] and [[diffusion of responsibility]] heavily relate to the volunteer’s dilemma.{{citation needed|date=May 2011}} ==Payoff matrix== The [[payoff matrix]] for the game is shown below: {| border cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" align="center"> |+ Volunteer's dilemma payoff matrix (example) | !scope="col" style="color: #900"|at least one other person cooperates !scope="col" style="color: #900"|all others defect |- !scope="row" style="color: #009"|cooperate |0 |0 |- !scope="row" style="color: #009"|defect |1 |−10 |- |} When the volunteer's dilemma takes place between only two players, the game gets the character of the game '[[Chicken (game)|chicken]]'. As seen by the payoff matrix, there is no dominant strategy in the volunteer’s dilemma. In a mixed-strategy [[Nash equilibrium]], an increase in N players will decrease the likelihood that at least one person volunteers, which is a result of the [[bystander effect]]. ==Examples in real life== ===The murder of Kitty Genovese=== The story of [[Kitty Genovese]] is often cited as an example of the volunteer's dilemma. Genovese was stabbed to death outside her apartment building in Queens, New York, in 1964. According to a highly influential ''New York Times'' account, dozens of people witnessed the assault but did not get involved because they thought others would contact the police anyway and did not want to incur the personal cost of getting involved.{{cite journal |last=Weesie |first=Jeroen |year=1993 |title=Asymmetry and Timing in the Volunteer's Dilemma |journal=[[Journal of Conflict Resolution]] |volume=37 |issue=3 |pages=569–590 |jstor=174269 |doi=10.1177/0022002793037003008}} Subsequent investigations have shown the original account to have been unfounded, and although it inspired sound scientific research, its use as a simplistic parable in psychology textbooks has been criticized.{{cite journal| last = Manning| first = R. |author2=Levine, M |author3=Collins, A.| title = The Kitty Genovese murder and the social psychology of helping: The parable of the 38 witnesses| journal = [[American Psychologist]]| volume = 62| issue = 6| pages = 555–562|date=September 2007 | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.62.6.555| pmid = 17874896 }} ===The meerkat=== The [[meerkat]] exhibits the volunteer's dilemma in nature. One or more meerkats act as sentries while the others forage for food. If a predator approaches, the sentry meerkat lets out a warning call so the others can burrow to safety. However, the altruism of this meerkat puts it at risk of being discovered by the predator. ==See also== * [[Bystander effect]] * [[Civil courage]] *[[Death of Cristina and Violetta Djeordsevic]] (Italy) * [[Death of Wang Yue]] (China) * [[Mamihlapinatapai]] * [[Prisoner's dilemma]] * [[Social loafing]] * [[Tragedy of the Commons]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Game theory}} [[Category:Non-cooperative games]] [[Category:Dilemmas]]
